video.title: Scratch Tutorial for Beginners - Make a Flappy Bird Game
video.description:
Learn how to use Scratch 3.0 by building a flappy bird game. This full tutorial course is prefect for beginners who want to learn Scratch. Scratch is a free programming language and online community where you can create your own interactive stories, games, and animations. Scratch is designed especially for ages 8 to 16, but is used by people of all ages.

🔗Official Scratch website: https://scratch.mit.edu

💻 Completed project: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/282380922/

🎥 Tutorial created by Warfame. Check out their Youtube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXJDb8HZ8Hz9HDxWL-wRvmg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Ruffian Eo
topLevelComment.text:
I am not sure if this is what the world needs. Graphical programming languages usually do not last very long. Even nearly graphical programming languages such as Smalltalk (squeak) are far from main stream. And if kids learn to use scratch at say age 12, they have a maximum time of about 2 years where it makes sense. 14-16 year old kids should be able to use an editor, not only for programming but also for vanilla text editing (homework, email, ...). Logo was an older incarnation of scratch (in spirit) and good old basic might be easy enough for even 12 year old kids to master.

I used to teach 14 year old kids with Pascal and because graphics is what keeps kids motivated, I wrote a small and simple graphics library for them to use. And they had no problems to get small things done. This was in 1990. While I would not use Pascal now in 2021, I still think even 12 year old kids might be able to handle some typing in a text editor. 

Given (at least in Germany), kids start to learn English around the age of 8, it might even be a good idea to show them an application for them learning a foreign language. So, there is no need for localized programming languages. We learned that back in the day when MS Office had localized Visual Basic and it was a mess.

topLevelComment.text: At 16:19, in the repeat until block, the condition used is xposition < -237. And the code inside the return block works till the condition is true. Then how does the code in the repeat until block execute?? I tried using x > -237, but it doesn't work. Someone please clarify.
